articles.headline: Deaths From Cantaloupe Listeria Rise
articles.snippet: At least 13 people, most of them elderly, have died after eating cantaloupe contaminated with listeria in the deadliest outbreak of food-borne illness in the United States in more than a decade.
articles.abstract: At least 13 people, most of them elderly, have died after eating cantaloupe contaminated with listeria in the deadliest outbreak of food-borne illness in the United States in more than a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: At least 13 people in eight states have died after eating cantaloupe contaminated with listeria, in the deadliest outbreak of food-borne illness in the United States in more than a decade, public health officials said on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Backing Indie Bands to Sell Cars
articles.snippet: Toyota has released music sporadically, but now it will sponsor a full campaign of record releases, videos and tour support for about 20 acts.
articles.abstract: Toyota has released music sporadically, but now it will sponsor a full campaign of record releases, videos and tour support for about 20 acts.
articles.lead_paragraph: A crowd of young music fans gathered outside the Roxy Theater in Hollywood one Saturday afternoon recently, jostling for free T-shirts. As Repulsion, a band of the grisly heavy-metal style known as grindcore, blasted through songs like “Pestilent Decay” and “Splattered Cadavers,” dozens of fans on their way in and out of the club scooped up the garments, printed with a gory design typical of the genre.

articles.headline: For Hackers, the Next Lock to Pick
articles.snippet: Although attacks are few at the moment, software developers say it’s only a matter of time before computer hackers follow the money to cellphones.
articles.abstract: Although attacks are few at the moment, software developers say it’s only a matter of time before computer hackers follow the money to cellphones.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Hackers have broken into the cellphones of celebrities like Scarlett Johansson and Prince William. But what about the rest of us, who might not have particularly salacious photos or voice messages stored in our phones, but nonetheless have e-mails, credit card numbers and records of our locations?

articles.headline: Even Those Cleared of Crimes Can Stay on F.B.I.’s Watch List
articles.snippet: A not-guilty verdict or dropped charges may not always be enough to get someone off the list, files show.
articles.abstract: A not-guilty verdict or dropped charges may not always be enough to get someone off the list, files show.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Bureau of Investigation is permitted to include people on the government’s terrorist watch list even if they have been acquitted of terrorism-related offenses or the charges are dropped, according to newly released documents.

articles.headline: As Scorn for Vote Grows, Protests Surge Around Globe
articles.snippet: Protesters around the world have something in common: wariness, even contempt, toward traditional politicians and the democratic political process they preside over.
articles.abstract: Protesters around the world have something in common: wariness, even contempt, toward traditional politicians and the democratic political process they preside over.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADRID — Hundreds of thousands of disillusioned Indians cheer a rural activist on a hunger strike. Israel reels before the largest street demonstrations in its history. Enraged young people in Spain and Greece take over public squares across their countries.

articles.headline: Health Insurers Push Premiums Sharply Higher
articles.snippet: The cost of health insurance this year rose more steeply than in previous years, outstripping wages and adding uncertainty about the pace of growing costs.
articles.abstract: The cost of health insurance this year rose more steeply than in previous years, outstripping wages and adding uncertainty about the pace of growing costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Major health insurance companies have been charging sharply higher premiums this year, outstripping any growth in workers’ wages and creating more uncertainty for the Obama administration and employers who are struggling to drive down an unrelenting rise in medical costs.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Nina Bernstein

articles.headline: Reebok to Pay Settlement Over Health Claims
articles.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission said the sportswear maker agreed to pay $25 million to settle allegations of unfounded claims about the health benefits of two lines of shoes.
articles.abstract: The Federal Trade Commission said the sportswear maker agreed to pay $25 million to settle allegations of unfounded claims about the health benefits of two lines of shoes.
articles.lead_paragraph: More dashed hopes for those seeking a perfect derrière — and the once highflying industry of toning shoes and clothing that promotes such ambitions.
articles.byline: By Andrew Martin and Anahad O'Connor

articles.headline: Amazon’s Tablet Leads to Its Store
articles.snippet: At $199, the color Kindle Fire is less than half the price of the Apple iPad.
articles.abstract: At $199, the color Kindle Fire is less than half the price of the Apple iPad.
articles.lead_paragraph: With a glossy 7-inch color touch screen and a dual-core processor, the Kindle Fire, a new mobile device introduced by Amazon on Wednesday, sure looks like a tablet, and one not so different from the Apple iPad.
articles.byline: By Jenna Wortham and David Streitfeld
